catalogue_raissonne: Hollstein 147 i/ii (before the number); Bartsch 12 (vol. 9, p. 94); Nagler Monogrammisten II, 498, 16; Van der Stock 19
creditline: Gift of Elizabeth, Julie, and Catherine Andrus in memory of John and Marion Andrus
description: couple walking, holding hands; male at L wears a badge and rests PL hand on a crutch, swinging his wooden peg leg forward; woman at R walking with a crutch with footless R leg forward
inscription:
Signature

-- inscribed in graphite on mount: [Cornelis Massys, Plate 10 Les Danseurs boiteux 1 of 2]
-- in graphite on verso: B.12 | R OR [with a line over the first R]
portfolio: From From La danse des estropiés, Plate 10
provenance: [French dealer.] John E. Andrus III, Wayzata, Minn.; by descent to his daughters, Elizabeth, Katie, and Julie; gave to MIA, 2015. Earlier provenances have been gathered, but further research will increase our knowledge of their histories.
text: Buying peasant images made the bourgeoisie feel good about their own social status, and a dollop of moralizing was a bonus. Dancing vagabonds typically were a reminder that dancing led to paganism, but Cornelis Massijs was probably also hoping for a laugh. He cast this pair hoofing it with the help of a crutch and cane.
title: The Lame Dancers, from La danse des estropiés, Plate 10
